intro: Let's explore how heat moves! Imagine two objects with different temperatures. What do you think happens to the heat energy between them?

questions.question: You have Object A at 80°C and Object B at 20°C. In which direction will heat flow?
options: Heat will flow from Object A to Object B.
Heat will flow from Object B to Object A.
Heat will not flow because they are different objects.
Heat will flow equally in both directions.
questions.hint: Remember, heat likes to spread out from where it's more concentrated to where it's less concentrated.

questions.question: If you touch a hot frying pan, which object is hotter?
questions.hint: Think about how your hand feels when you touch something very hot.

questions.question: What happens to the temperature of Object A (initially 80°C) if it's placed next to Object B (initially 20°C)?
options: Object A's temperature will stay the same.
Object A's temperature will fluctuate wildly.
questions.hint: Heat flows from hotter to colder objects. What effect does losing heat have on an object's temperature?

followups: As heat flows from Object A to Object B, their temperatures move closer together.
This process continues until both objects reach the same temperature, a state called thermal equilibrium.
summary: Heat always flows from a hotter object to a colder object, working to even out temperatures.
